issues.description: Type of Person.birthday is inconsistent across artifacts and within the solution. The problem statement's UML and the template common model declare Person.birthday as java.time.LocalDate, and the client view code (PersonScene) expects a LocalDate (uses DatePicker.setValue(LocalDate)). However, the solution repository's common Person model defines birthday as String. This mismatch (LocalDate vs String) is structural and will cause compile-time/type errors (client code expecting LocalDate while the shared model provides String) or student confusion about which type to use when implementing or testing. It also contradicts the problem specification which explicitly lists birthday as LocalDate.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Person.birthday type consistent across all artifacts. The simplest correction preserving the problem intent is to change the solution repository's common Person.birthday from String to java.time.LocalDate (and adjust any JSON serialization/deserialization configuration if needed). Alternatively, if the project intends to use String, update the problem statement and all client/server code (PersonScene, controllers, services) to use String and convert to/from LocalDate where appropriate, but prefer using LocalDate to match the UML and template model.

issues.description: Typo / incorrect parameter type in the problem statement for Part 2: the text says "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter" when it is describing the PersonController methods. The intended type is Consumer<List<Person>> (the template method signatures use Consumer<List<Person>>). This wording mistake in the problem statement may confuse students about the expected callback parameter type.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement text to say "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Person>> parameter" (and that the consumer receives the controller's internal list of persons). This aligns the description with the template method signatures and avoids confusion.
